--- title: "Excel first steps" execute: echo: false freeze: auto categories: [excel, beginner] --- ## Previous attendees have said... - 12 previous attendees have left feedback - 100% said that this session was pitched correctly - 100% would recommend this session to a colleague :::{.callout-note} ### Three random comments from previous attendees - Informative and helpful - The session was really good, I've been using excel almost daily for years and learned some really simple things that I didn't know which will make working with it so much quicker and easier. - Very informative, well presented, easy to understand. ::: - [slides](src/excel_first_steps_sl.html) / [pdf slides](src/excel_first_steps_sl.pdf) for this session ## Welcome! - this session is ðŸŒ¶: a beginner-level introduction - you're very welcome to just watch, but if you want to follow along, you'll need Excel of some sort - totally informal and chatty, so cameras on etc etc - also want to plug [the M365 Skills Hub for NHSS folks](https://scottish.sharepoint.com/sites/NHSSLearningPathways) ## Session outline ![](images/mermaid-diagram-2024-06-20-124115.png){width="100%"} ## A brief overview of Excel ![](images/clipboard-965547330.png){width="60%"} - one of the oldest, and most widely used, pieces of desktop software - ubiquitous in business, finance, health and social care... - proprietary, closed-source, paid-for - many versions ## Central idea - pieces of data are stored in cells - one value, one cell - cells are arranged into rows and columns
![](images/clipboard-1879510795.png){width="60%"} - arranging data like this allows us to analyse it - good data analysis helps make services better ## Data should help... - answering which/when questions - seeing effects of changes - comparing different areas - looking at services over time - ... ## One word of warning before the practical part - there are lots of versions of Excel - they all work slightly differently - please don't panic if what you see looks slightly different from what I'm showing you - please ask if you're not happy/confident! ## Opening Excel (desktop) ![](images/clipboard-1394052793.png) ![](images/clipboard-2150015829.png) ## Opening Excel (web) ![](images/clipboard-3067626588.png) ## Interface ![](images/interface.png){width="90%"} ## Save, close, open ![](images/clipboard-3187630465.png){height="40%"} ![](images/clipboard-1979369937.png){height="40%"} - save your new workbook - close it - re-open it (possibly from recent files) ## References - every cell in Excel has a **reference** - like its address - references look like this: `E7`
![](images/cols.png) - `E` refers to a vertical column - `7` to a horizontal row ## Data entry - let's add some data... - we can type into the cells
![](images/clipboard-1771455666.png) - that data appears in the formula bar too ## An example: school holidays - https://www.scotborders.gov.uk/schools-learning/term-holiday-closure-dates/2 - make three headings in row 1: `name`, `start_date`, `end_date`
![](images/clipboard-1395187747.png) ## Values - let's add some values from the school holidays webpage - name of holiday - start date - end date - dates usually go `DD/MM/YYYY` - as we'll see, Excel does lots of helping when we enter dates... - ...ðŸ˜± - we'll only need a few rows of data ::: notes name start_date end_date Mid-term holidays 14/10/2024 18/10/2024 In service day 21/10/2024 21/10/2024 St Andrew's Day 02/12/2024 02/12/2024 ::: ## Tidy data - keep things consistent - spelling, case, formats, etc - one piece of data per cell - one instance per row (one school holiday per row) - one variable per column (a column of names, one of start dates...) ## Tables - we can convert this group of cells into a proper **table** - click in one of your cells of data
![](images/clipboard-1117112977.png) - `Insert` \> `Table` (or `Ctrl` + `T`)
![](images/clipboard-166790706.png) - click `OK`
![](images/clipboard-77557231.png) ## Lots of new things to see ![](images/clipboard-1614882971.png) ## Autofill - we'll add a formula to calculate how long our holidays are - add a new column called `days` - paste `= 1 + (C2 - B2)` into the first cell of that new column - and look out for our session on formulas... - double-click the green fill handle to fill the rest of the column
![](images/clipboard-1731283483.png) ## Formatting - we can change the way that our spreadsheet looks - we can also change the way our values look ## Cell formatting - some examples
![](images/clipboard-4175540765.png) - highlighting - bold - borders ## Number formatting - our dates are **number formatted** - Excel dates are actually numbers (like `45583`) formatted to look like dates - 1900 dates! - percentages, Â£, ... ## Conditional formatting - we can also format based on values
![](images/clipboard-3358194074.png) - take care though - this can be both ugly, and inaccessible
